qas.question: Who was the political guide during the Protestant Reformation?
Who was the spiritual guide during the Protestant Reformation?
Who spent several years as a political refugee in the city?
How many other cities joined Strasbourg at the Imperial Diet of Augsburg in 1530?
In what decade did Jacob Sturm von Sturmeck start offering political guidance to Strasbourg?
In what decade did Martin Luther start his religious teachings?
In what city was John Calvin born?
In what year was Charles V made Holy Roman Emperor?
In what city was Charle V declared Holy Roman Emperor?

context: In the <b4_0><b5_0>1520s<b5_0/><b4_0/> during the Protestant Reformation, the city, under the political guidance of <a0_0>Jacob Sturm von Sturmeck<a0_0/> and the spiritual guidance of <a1_0>Martin Bucer<a1_0/> embraced the religious teachings of Martin Luther. Their adherents established a Gymnasium, headed by Johannes Sturm, made into a University in the following century. The city first followed the Tetrapolitan Confession, and then the <b8_0>Augsburg<b8_0/> Confession. Protestant iconoclasm caused much destruction to churches and cloisters, notwithstanding that Luther himself opposed such a practice. Strasbourg was a centre of humanist scholarship and early book-printing in the Holy Roman Empire, and its intellectual and political influence contributed much to the establishment of Protestantism as an accepted denomination in the southwest of Germany. (<a2_0>John Calvin<a2_0/> spent several years as a political refugee in the city). The <b6_0>Strasbourg<b6_0/> Councillor Sturm and guildmaster Matthias represented the city at the Imperial Diet of Speyer (1529), where their protest led to the schism of the Catholic Church and the evolution of Protestantism. Together with <a3_0>four<a3_0/> other free cities, Strasbourg presented the confessio tetrapolitana as its Protestant book of faith at the Imperial Diet of Augsburg in <b7_0>1530<b7_0/>, where the slightly different Augsburg Confession was also handed over to Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor.
